ygData.subject: RE: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?
ygData.msgSnippet: I think we are basically on the same page but expressing it with different words. I agree that a clients lack of adhering to the constraints does not diminish

I think we are basically on the same page but expressing it with different
=
words. I agree that a clients lack of adhering to the constraints does not
=
diminish the server. My point is that the client not playing well does
dimi=
nish the overall benefit. For example it might mean the client is
broken wh=
en the server evolves.

Sent from my Windows Phone
------------------------=
------
From: Juan Lanus
Sent: 3/11/2012 12:08 PM
To: Glenn Block
Cc: Willia=
m Martinez Pomares; rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss=
] Re: Does the client contribute to the
RESTfulness of an application?

Hi =
Glenn, All,
No, there is not an agreement, not at all. But IMO this interes=
ting thread
is are moving in the direction of one.
It looks to me that it m=
ight be something like

   - RESTful are the services, in the server,
   - =
that RESTfulness is not affected by the lack of it in the client, and
   - =
calling a client *RESTful *actually means that it leverages to a great
   e=
xtent the advantages of the server's RESTfulness.

--
Juan

On Sun, Mar 11,=
 2012 at 15:21, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> "IMO this thr=
ead is so lengthy because it started with a "RESTful system"
> idea which I=
MO is a wild horse"
>
> Is it? I don't think there is general agreement on =
that statement as Jan
> and others have pointed out.
>
>
> Sent from my Win=
dows Phone
> ------------------------------
> From: Juan Lanus
> Sent: 3/11=
/2012 6:26 AM
> To: William Martinez Pomares
> Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogroups=
.com
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the
> =
RESTfulness of an application?
>
>
>
> > "A client not obeying the rules do=
es not necessarily remove all benefits
> of
> > REST for the server, though=
 it can if it is the ONLY client."
>
> I don't get this. For example, if I =
had a fully RESTful server publishing
> a public service consumed by one an=
d only one fully REST-compliant client,
> and somebody created another clie=
nt which is not REST-compliant, then what?
>  Would the service be deprived=
 of it's badge?
> Of course it won't!
>
> IMO this thread is so lengthy bec=
ause it started with a "RESTful system"
> idea which IMO is a wild horse, t=
he RESTful certificate is only for
> services (the server) and clients can =
leverage RESTfulness or not, at will,
> without affecting the service's qua=
lity.
>
> The client can't be RESTful, as it does not communicate with its =
(human
> client) user through HTTP.
> --
> JL
>
>  
>

--f46d04016ab9fa974a04bafdbbd3
